**G.L. c. 186, \u00a714**.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to **G.L. c. 186, §14**, which provides tenants a statutory right to recover damages for a landlord’s interference with the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A**.proposition: The lack of proper maintenance and failure to repair violates **G.L. c. 186, §14**, **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, and public policy as announced in *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **379 Mass. 196** (1979).

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment “is violated when the landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s right to the premises.”
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reframes Massachusetts quiet enjoyment law to focus on the landlord’s conduct (acts or omissions) and the resulting substantial interference, rather than on intent. The court states that a breach occurs where interference with the tenant’s rights is the “natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done,” and applies that standard to find a violation based on the landlords’ failure to control noise. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant is violated when the landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s right to the premises.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714**.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417 Mass. 273** (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act despite notice of the defective condition constitutes an **“omission”** within the meaning of *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417 Mass. 273** (1994).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets the quiet enjoyment statute to cover not only affirmative acts but also failures to act. The court states that a breach can be a “natural and probable consequence” of “what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done,” and then applies that principle to the housing authority’s inaction despite notice of criminal activity. Thus, the decision treats the landlord’s failure to act after notice as an omission that can constitute actionable interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, **417.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.proposition: Massachusetts precedent holds that where a landlord’s failure to repair creates uninhabitable conditions, the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is breached.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions as violations of the landlord’s duty to maintain habitable, sanitary premises and links that duty to the statutory and common-law right of quiet enjoyment. The court holds that Gem’s failure to prevent repeated flooding—an uninhabitable, unsanitary condition—both breached the warranty of habitability and constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This squarely supports the proposition that a landlord’s failure to repair resulting in uninhabitable conditions breaches the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91** (19.relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question... that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Davis v. Comerford*, **483 Mass. 164**.proposition: Massachusetts precedent holds that where a landlord’s failure to repair creates uninhabitable conditions, the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is breached.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.proposition: The lack of proper maintenance and failure to repair violates **G.L. c. 186, §14**, **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, and public policy as announced in *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **379 Mass. 196** (1979).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses rent abatement for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and interprets G.L. c. 239, § 8A as legislative support for allowing withholding/abatement without regard to landlord fault. It does not hold that lack of proper maintenance or failure to repair, in itself, constitutes a statutory violation of G.L. c. 186, §14 or c. 239, §8A, nor does it frame this as a broad public policy rule under those statutes. The case is primarily about common-law warranty of habitability and timing of rent abatement, not about statutory violations for failure to maintain or repair under the cited sections.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.relevant_excerpt: “When the tenant’s loss of heat occurred, G. L. c. 239, § 8A, permitted the tenant to withhold rent for Code violations only if ‘the owner . . . had not taken reasonable steps to remedy such conditions.’ … In 1977, the Legislature struck this provision. … The tenant may now withhold rent without considering whether the landlord is at fault or is taking reasonable steps to repair. As was the case in Hemingway, this statute provides for rent withholding, not rent abatement; but, as in Hemingway, we choose to permit a rent abatement as a matter of common law.”

*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, **4.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law in every residential lease in Massachusetts.
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, **4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the evolution from independent to mutually dependent covenants in leases and contrasts commercial and residential doctrines, including the implied warranty of habitability in residential leases. However, it does not state that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law in every residential lease in Massachusetts. The focus is commercial leases, and residential law is mentioned only to describe habitability and background, not to articulate an implied quiet enjoyment covenant rule.
*Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc.*, **4.relevant_excerpt: “As it applied to residential leases, the independent covenants rule was completely supplanted in 1973, when we recognized that a residential ‘lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises.’ … This trend culminated in the almost universally recognized warranty of habitability implied in residential leases.”

*Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s course of conduct, as described herein, constitutes direct and indirect interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of *Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct. 744** (2005), and *Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct. 982** (1982).
*Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that the defendant’s (landlord’s) course of conduct constitutes direct and indirect interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of Jablonski. In Jablonski, however, the Appeals Court affirms the trial judge’s finding that there was no breach of the covenant or statutory right of quiet enjoyment and expressly states it sees no evidence of interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case stands for the absence of interference on facts where the landlord responded promptly to conditions, not for finding such interference, so it does not support the asserted proposition.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions. While these conditions were documented by the board of health pursuant to an inspection, a reinspection less than two weeks later indicated that substantially all the conditions had been satisfactorily addressed. The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant’s course of conduct, as described herein, constitutes direct and indirect interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of *Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct. 744** (2005), and *Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct. 982** (1982).
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: Lowery squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat, in violation of statutory and sanitary code requirements, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct and its natural consequences, not on intent or financial ability. That principle directly supports the broad proposition that a landlord’s course of conduct (here, failure to provide an essential service) can amount to direct or indirect interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of § 14 and subsequent cases like Jablonski.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s breaches and statutory violations, Plaintiff is entitled to recovery under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, *Simon v. Solomon*, supra; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855** (1991); *Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct. 907** (1987); and *Miles v. Werner*, **39 Mass. App. Ct. 910** (1995).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.support_reasoning: Haddad v. Gonzalez involves claims under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment) but the Housing Court judge, to avoid cumulative damages, dismissed all counterclaims except retaliation (c. 186, § 18) and c. 93A. The SJC’s opinion affirms recovery under c. 93A and for retaliation, and discusses measure of habitability damages, but does not award or analyze damages under § 14 as a basis of the ultimate recovery. Thus, it does not stand as authority that a plaintiff is entitled to recovery under G.L. c. 186, § 14 in the way the proposition cites it.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855**.relevant_excerpt: “After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability), and attorneys' fees and costs… Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s breaches and statutory violations, Plaintiff is entitled to recovery under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, *Simon v. Solomon*, supra; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855** (1991); *Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct. 907** (1987); and *Miles v. Werner*, **39 Mass. App. Ct. 910** (1995).
*Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns tenant recovery under G.L. c. 186, §14 (the Massachusetts quiet enjoyment/lockout statute). Young v. Patukonis involves claims for failure to provide utilities under the State Sanitary Code, violations of the security deposit statute (G.L. c. 186, §15B), Boston rent control ordinance overcharges, breach of warranty of habitability, and c. 93A inapplicability. The opinion does not mention or analyze G.L. c. 186, §14 at all, so it does not provide authority for recovery under that statute.
*Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: In finding that Young violated the requirements of the security deposit statute, the judge limited the tenant’s damage award to interest of $5.21. He refused to grant treble damages under § 15B (7) of the statute because the tenant was still in possession and the deposit had been returned. Patukonis argues that she is entitled to treble damages, interest and attorney’s fees for the breach of § 15B (3) (a), & 6 (a). The question has been answered in Patukonis’s favor by the recent case of Castenholz v. Caira, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 758 (1986).

*Miles v. Werner*, **39 Mass. App. Ct. 9.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s breaches and statutory violations, Plaintiff is entitled to recovery under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, *Simon v. Solomon*, supra; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, **410 Mass. 855** (1991); *Young v. Patukonis*, **24 Mass. App. Ct. 907** (1987); and *Miles v. Werner*, **39 Mass. App. Ct. 910** (1995).
*Miles v. Werner*, **39 Mass. App. Ct. 9.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a tenant’s right to recover under G.L. c. 186, §14 and related landlord-tenant/habitability remedies. Miles v. Werner is a criminal OUI case addressing delay in access to a bail magistrate and the right under G.L. c. 263, §5A to obtain an independent medical examination; it has nothing to do with landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, §14, or civil damages. Citing Miles v. Werner as authority for recovery under c. 186, §14 is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the opinion.
*Miles v. Werner*, **39 Mass. App. Ct. 9.relevant_excerpt: “2. Alleged violation of G. L. c. 263, § 5A. The judge’s decision in this case was made prior to the recent cases of Commonwealth v. Hampe, 419 Mass. 514 (1995), Commonwealth v. Priestley, 419 Mass. 678 (1995), and Commonwealth v. Chistolini, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 966… The governing statute, G. L. c. 263, § 5A… provides: ‘A person held in custody at a police station… charged with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor, shall have the right… to be examined immediately by a physician….’”}
